awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: Student Engagement in a Community-based,  Blended Learning Environment: Perspectives from a Minority Serving Institution
awd_abstract_narration:
There has been significant discussion regarding the retention of underrepresented groups in STEM, with the primary focus being on what works to ensure that these individuals successfully transition through each juncture of the STEM pipeline. Additionally, there is a significant body of work characterizing the deficits of students of color who struggle in STEM learning environments, with less focus on their narratives of success. This project seeks to creatively address this gap in the educational research literature by providing empirical data that describes factors that influence minority student success in blended learning environments.  It is envisioned that the work will lead to a better understanding of minority female students as agents of their own success and Spelman's learning environment as one which nurtures and encourages such agency. Few studies of this nature have been conducted at minority serving institutions. 

Based on prior NSF funding, the PIs successfully merged a community-based element with a blended learning environment in Spelman's general and organic chemistry courses. In the proposed work, they plan to document what is occurring in this learning environment with respect to engagement (metacognitive, cognitive, behavioral, and relational) and affective traits that comprise a student's sense of agency (motivation, efficacy, effort, and mindset). The PIs have constructed a solid well-conceived theoretical framework for their investigations. They are taking three different perspectives: agency, metacognition, and "Community of Inquiry" (CoI) and using them to examine the nature of the self-regulated learning exhibited by the students. Using a mixed methods approach to get information on "narratives of success" within the environment, the project entails the extraction of data from a well-established and controlled setting at Spelman College. The project has the potential to complement efforts around the country to create curricula and learning environments that transform students, particularly minority women, into effective learners.

por.por_cntn:
By employing modern theories of learning such as metacognitive skillfulness, agency, and inquiry-based learning, the NSF funding assisted the PIs in creating a chemistry learning environment at Spelman College where African American women can gain critical thinking skills to thrive in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics. The project focused on authentic learning experiences that nurtured the agency of academically mobile students. To this end, the PIs propose a longitudinal study of the engagement (metacognitive, cognitive, behavioral, and relational) in this environment and the affective traits that comprise students’ sense of agency (motivation, efficacy, effort, and mindset).  The analysis of student engagement during course activities has been facilitated through the video recording of small groups in the General Chemistry I and II (17 videos capturing 3 different group activities) and Organic Chemistry I (15 videos capturing 3 different group activities) courses and in the organic chemistry workshops (51 videos capturing 9 different group activities). New inquiry-based activities were created for both the general and organic chemistry sequences. Peer-peer engagement strategies were examined to understand how students influence the agency of their peers. Group quizzes were created that encourage interactive engagement through discussing solutions, challenging a peer’s response, affirming peers' knowledge, and allowing students to develop confidence in their ability to learn the information. The chemistry learning center was expanded to provide students with additional support beyond the classroom. The learning center was re-imagined as a virtual tool during the COVID pandemic. Likewise, the organic chemistry workshops were created to support student learning outside the classroom and converted to online tools to improve student access to the resource. As the college transitioned to more online instruction via a wintermester and summer online, many of the techniques developed in the project informed teaching and the development of curricular resources in these spaces. The authentic learning component of the work was leverage to expand active and culturally relevant pedagogies in the laboratory courses.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2023
Modified by: Leyte L Winfield
